column2: At the expiration of a year the governor was transferred; he had obtained charge of the fortress at Ham.
column3: At the expiration of a year the governor was transferred; he had obtained charge of the fortress at Ham.

column2: He took with him several of his subordinates, and amongst them Dantes' jailer.
column3: He took with him several of his subordinates, and amongst them Dantes' jailer.

column2: A new governor arrived; it would have been too tedious to acquire the names of the prisoners; he learned their numbers instead.
column3: A new governor arrived; it would have been too tedious to acquire the names of the prisoners; he learned their numbers instead.

column2: This horrible place contained fifty cells; their inhabitants were designated by the numbers of their cell, and the unhappy young man was no longer called Edmond Dantes--he was now number 34.
column3: This horrible place contained fifty cells; their inhabitants were designated by the numbers of their cell, and the unhappy young man was no longer called Edmond Dantes-he was now number thirty four.

column2: Chapter 15.
column3: Chapter fifteen.

column2: Number 34 and Number 27.
column3: Number thirty four and Number twenty seven.

column2: Dantes passed through all the stages of torture natural to prisoners in suspense.
column3: Dantes passed through all the stages of torture natural to prisoners in suspense.

column2: He was sustained at first by that pride of conscious innocence which is the sequence to hope; then he began to doubt his own innocence, which justified in some measure the governor's belief in his mental alienation; and then, relaxing his sentiment of pride, he addressed his supplications, not to God, but to man.
column3: He was sustained at first by that pride of conscious innocence which is the sequence to hope; then he began to doubt his own innocence, which justified in some measure the governor's belief in his mental alienation; and then, relaxing his sentiment of pride, he addressed his supplications, not to God, but to man.

column2: God is always the last resource. Unfortunates, who ought to begin with God, do not have any hope in him till they have exhausted all other means of deliverance.
column3: God is always the last resource. Unfortunates, who ought to begin with God, do not have any hope in him till they have exhausted all other means of deliverance.

column2: Dantes asked to be removed from his present dungeon into another; for a change, however disadvantageous, was still a change, and would afford him some amusement.
column3: Dantes asked to be removed from his present dungeon into another; for a change, however disadvantageous, was still a change, and would afford him some amusement.

column2: He entreated to be allowed to walk about, to have fresh air, books, and writing materials.
column3: He entreated to be allowed to walk about, to have fresh air, books, and writing materials.

column2: His requests were not granted, but he went on asking all the same.
column3: His requests were not granted, but he went on asking all the same.

column2: He accustomed himself to speaking to the new jailer, although the latter was, if possible, more taciturn than the old one; but still, to speak to a man, even though mute, was something.
column3: He accustomed himself to speaking to the new jailer, although the latter was, if possible, more taciturn than the old one; but still, to speak to a man, even though mute, was something.

column2: Dantes spoke for the sake of hearing his own voice; he had tried to speak when alone, but the sound of his voice terrified him. Often, before his captivity, Dantes' mind had revolted at the idea of assemblages of prisoners, made up of thieves, vagabonds, and murderers. He now wished to be amongst them, in order to see some other face besides that of his jailer; he sighed for the galleys, with the infamous costume, the chain, and the brand on the shoulder.
column3: Dantes spoke for the sake of hearing his own voice; he had tried to speak when alone, but the sound of his voice terrified him. Often, before his captivity, Dantes' mind had revolted at the idea of assemblages of prisoners, made up of thieves, vagabonds, and murderers. He now wished to be amongst them, in order to see some other face besides that of his jailer; he sighed for the galleys, with the infamous costume, the chain, and the brand on the shoulder.

column2: The galley-slaves breathed the fresh air of heaven, and saw each other.
column3: The galley slaves breathed the fresh air of heaven, and saw each other.

column2: They were very happy.
column3: They were very happy.

column2: He besought the jailer one day to let him have a companion, were it even the mad abbe.
column3: He besought the jailer one day to let him have a companion, were it even the mad abbe.

column2: The jailer, though rough and hardened by the constant sight of so much suffering, was yet a man.
column3: The jailer, though rough and hardened by the constant sight of so much suffering, was yet a man.

column2: At the bottom of his heart he had often had a feeling of pity for this unhappy young man who suffered so; and he laid the request of number 34 before the governor; but the latter sapiently imagined that Dantes wished to conspire or attempt an escape, and refused his request.
column3: At the bottom of his heart he had often had a feeling of pity for this unhappy young man who suffered so; and he laid the request of number thirty four before the governor; but the latter sapiently imagined that Dantes wished to conspire or attempt an escape, and refused his request.

column2: Dantes had exhausted all human resources, and he then turned to God.
column3: Dantes had exhausted all human resources, and he then turned to God.

column2: All the pious ideas that had been so long forgotten, returned; he recollected the prayers his mother had taught him, and discovered a new meaning in every word; for in prosperity prayers seem but a mere medley of words, until misfortune comes and the unhappy sufferer first understands the meaning of the sublime language in which he invokes the pity of heaven!
column3: All the pious ideas that had been so long forgotten, returned; he recollected the prayers his mother had taught him, and discovered a new meaning in every word; for in prosperity prayers seem but a mere medley of words, until misfortune comes and the unhappy sufferer first understands the meaning of the sublime language in which he invokes the pity of heaven!

column2: He prayed, and prayed aloud, no longer terrified at the sound of his own voice, for he fell into a sort of ecstasy.
column3: He prayed, and prayed aloud, no longer terrified at the sound of his own voice, for he fell into a sort of ecstasy.

column2: He laid every action of his life before the Almighty, proposed tasks to accomplish, and at the end of every prayer introduced the entreaty oftener addressed to man than to God: "Forgive us our trespasses as we forgive them that trespass against us." Yet in spite of his earnest prayers, Dantes remained a prisoner.
column3: He laid every action of his life before the Almighty, proposed tasks to accomplish, and at the end of every prayer introduced the entreaty oftener addressed to man than to God: "Forgive us our trespasses as we forgive them that trespass against us." Yet in spite of his earnest prayers, Dantes remained a prisoner.

column2: Then gloom settled heavily upon him.
column3: Then gloom settled heavily upon him.

column2: Dantes was a man of great simplicity of thought, and without education; he could not, therefore, in the solitude of his dungeon, traverse in mental vision the history of the ages, bring to life the nations that had perished, and rebuild the ancient cities so vast and stupendous in the light of the imagination, and that pass before the eye glowing with celestial colors in Martin's Babylonian pictures.
column3: Dantes was a man of great simplicity of thought, and without education; he could not, therefore, in the solitude of his dungeon, traverse in mental vision the history of the ages, bring to life the nations that had perished, and rebuild the ancient cities so vast and stupendous in the light of the imagination, and that pass before the eye glowing with celestial colors in Martin's Babylonian pictures.

column2: He could not do this, he whose past life was so short, whose present so melancholy, and his future so doubtful.
column3: He could not do this, he whose past life was so short, whose present so melancholy, and his future so doubtful.

column2: Nineteen years of light to reflect upon in eternal darkness!
column3: Nineteen years of light to reflect upon in eternal darkness!

column2: No distraction could come to his aid; his energetic spirit, that would have exalted in thus revisiting the past, was imprisoned like an eagle in a cage.
column3: No distraction could come to his aid; his energetic spirit, that would have exalted in thus revisiting the past, was imprisoned like an eagle in a cage.

column2: He clung to one idea--that of his happiness, destroyed, without apparent cause, by an unheard-of fatality; he considered and reconsidered this idea, devoured it (so to speak), as the implacable Ugolino devours the skull of Archbishop Roger in the Inferno of Dante.
column3: He clung to one idea-that of his happiness, destroyed, without apparent cause, by an unheard of fatality; he considered and reconsidered this idea, devoured it (so to speak), as the implacable Ugolino devours the skull of Archbishop Roger in the Inferno of Dante.

column2: Rage supplanted religious fervor.
column3: Rage supplanted religious fervor.

column2: Dantes uttered blasphemies that made his jailer recoil with horror, dashed himself furiously against the walls of his prison, wreaked his anger upon everything, and chiefly upon himself, so that the least thing,--a grain of sand, a straw, or a breath of air that annoyed him, led to paroxysms of fury.
column3: Dantes uttered blasphemies that made his jailer recoil with horror, dashed himself furiously against the walls of his prison, wreaked his anger upon everything, and chiefly upon himself, so that the least thing,--a grain of sand, a straw, or a breath of air that annoyed him, led to paroxysms of fury.

column2: Then the letter that Villefort had showed to him recurred to his mind, and every line gleamed forth in fiery letters on the wall like the mene tekel upharsin of Belshazzar.
column3: Then the letter that Villefort had showed to him recurred to his mind, and every line gleamed forth in fiery letters on the wall like the mene tekel upharsin of Belshazzar.

column2: He told himself that it was the enmity of man, and not the vengeance of heaven, that had thus plunged him into the deepest misery. He consigned his unknown persecutors to the most horrible tortures he could imagine, and found them all insufficient, because after torture came death, and after death, if not repose, at least the boon of unconsciousness.
column3: He told himself that it was the enmity of man, and not the vengeance of heaven, that had thus plunged him into the deepest misery. He consigned his unknown persecutors to the most horrible tortures he could imagine, and found them all insufficient, because after torture came death, and after death, if not repose, at least the boon of unconsciousness.

column2: By dint of constantly dwelling on the idea that tranquillity was death, and if punishment were the end in view other tortures than death must be invented, he began to reflect on suicide.
column3: By dint of constantly dwelling on the idea that tranquillity was death, and if punishment were the end in view other tortures than death must be invented, he began to reflect on suicide.

column2: Unhappy he, who, on the brink of misfortune, broods over ideas like these!
column3: Unhappy he, who, on the brink of misfortune, broods over ideas like these!

column2: Before him is a dead sea that stretches in azure calm before the eye; but he who unwarily ventures within its embrace finds himself struggling with a monster that would drag him down to perdition.
column3: Before him is a dead sea that stretches in azure calm before the eye; but he who unwarily ventures within its embrace finds himself struggling with a monster that would drag him down to perdition.

column2: Once thus ensnared, unless the protecting hand of God snatch him thence, all is over, and his struggles but tend to hasten his destruction.
column3: Once thus ensnared, unless the protecting hand of God snatch him thence, all is over, and his struggles but tend to hasten his destruction.

column2: This state of mental anguish is, however, less terrible than the sufferings that precede or the punishment that possibly will follow.
column3: This state of mental anguish is, however, less terrible than the sufferings that precede or the punishment that possibly will follow.

column2: There is a sort of consolation at the contemplation of the yawning abyss, at the bottom of which lie darkness and obscurity.
column3: There is a sort of consolation at the contemplation of the yawning abyss, at the bottom of which lie darkness and obscurity.

column2: Edmond found some solace in these ideas.
column3: Edmond found some solace in these ideas.

column2: All his sorrows, all his sufferings, with their train of gloomy spectres, fled from his cell when the angel of death seemed about to enter.
column3: All his sorrows, all his sufferings, with their train of gloomy spectres, fled from his cell when the angel of death seemed about to enter.

column2: Dantes reviewed his past life with composure, and, looking forward with terror to his future existence, chose that middle line that seemed to afford him a refuge.
column3: Dantes reviewed his past life with composure, and, looking forward with terror to his future existence, chose that middle line that seemed to afford him a refuge.

column2: Sometimes, said he, "in my voyages, when I was a man and commanded other men, I have seen the heavens overcast, the sea rage and foam, the storm arise, and, like a monstrous bird, beating the two horizons with its wings.
column3: Sometimes, said he, "in my voyages, when I was a man and commanded other men, I have seen the heavens overcast, the sea rage and foam, the storm arise, and, like a monstrous bird, beating the two horizons with its wings.

column2: Then I felt that my vessel was a vain refuge, that trembled and shook before the tempest.
column3: Then I felt that my vessel was a vain refuge, that trembled and shook before the tempest.

column2: Soon the fury of the waves and the sight of the sharp rocks announced the approach of death, and death then terrified me, and I used all my skill and intelligence as a man and a sailor to struggle against the wrath of God.
column3: Soon the fury of the waves and the sight of the sharp rocks announced the approach of death, and death then terrified me, and I used all my skill and intelligence as a man and a sailor to struggle against the wrath of God.

column2: But I did so because I was happy, because I had not courted death, because to be cast upon a bed of rocks and seaweed seemed terrible, because I was unwilling that I, a creature made for the service of God, should serve for food to the gulls and ravens.
column3: But I did so because I was happy, because I had not courted death, because to be cast upon a bed of rocks and seaweed seemed terrible, because I was unwilling that I, a creature made for the service of God, should serve for food to the gulls and ravens.

column2: But now it is different; I have lost all that bound me to life, death smiles and invites me to repose; I die after my own manner, I die exhausted and broken-spirited, as I fall asleep when I have paced three thousand times round my cell."
column3: But now it is different; I have lost all that bound me to life, death smiles and invites me to repose; I die after my own manner, I die exhausted and broken spirited, as I fall asleep when I have paced three thousand times round my cell."

column2: No sooner had this idea taken possession of him than he became more composed, arranged his couch to the best of his power, ate little and slept less, and found existence almost supportable, because he felt that he could throw it off at pleasure, like a worn-out garment.
column3: No sooner had this idea taken possession of him than he became more composed, arranged his couch to the best of his power, ate little and slept less, and found existence almost supportable, because he felt that he could throw it off at pleasure, like a worn out garment.

column2: Two methods of self-destruction were at his disposal.
column3: Two methods of self destruction were at his disposal.

column2: He could hang himself with his handkerchief to the window bars, or refuse food and die of starvation. But the first was repugnant to him.
column3: He could hang himself with his handkerchief to the window bars, or refuse food and die of starvation. But the first was repugnant to him.

column2: Dantes had always entertained the greatest horror of pirates, who are hung up to the yard-arm; he would not die by what seemed an infamous death.
column3: Dantes had always entertained the greatest horror of pirates, who are hung up to the yard arm; he would not die by what seemed an infamous death.

column2: He resolved to adopt the second, and began that day to carry out his resolve.
column3: He resolved to adopt the second, and began that day to carry out his resolve.

column2: Nearly four years had passed away; at the end of the second he had ceased to mark the lapse of time.
column3: Nearly four years had passed away; at the end of the second he had ceased to mark the lapse of time.

column2: Dantes said, "I wish to die," and had chosen the manner of his death, and fearful of changing his mind, he had taken an oath to die.
column3: Dantes said, "I wish to die," and had chosen the manner of his death, and fearful of changing his mind, he had taken an oath to die.

column2: When my morning and evening meals are brought, thought he, "I will cast them out of the window, and they will think that I have eaten them."
column3: When my morning and evening meals are brought, thought he, "I will cast them out of the window, and they will think that I have eaten them."

column2: He kept his word; twice a day he cast out, through the barred aperture, the provisions his jailer brought him--at first gayly, then with deliberation, and at last with regret.
column3: He kept his word; twice a day he cast out, through the barred aperture, the provisions his jailer brought him-at first gayly, then with deliberation, and at last with regret.

column2: Nothing but the recollection of his oath gave him strength to proceed.
column3: Nothing but the recollection of his oath gave him strength to proceed.

column2: Hunger made viands once repugnant, now acceptable; he held the plate in his hand for an hour at a time, and gazed thoughtfully at the morsel of bad meat, of tainted fish, of black and mouldy bread.
column3: Hunger made viands once repugnant, now acceptable; he held the plate in his hand for an hour at a time, and gazed thoughtfully at the morsel of bad meat, of tainted fish, of black and mouldy bread.

column2: It was the last yearning for life contending with the resolution of despair; then his dungeon seemed less sombre, his prospects less desperate.
column3: It was the last yearning for life contending with the resolution of despair; then his dungeon seemed less sombre, his prospects less desperate.

column2: He was still young--he was only four or five and twenty--he had nearly fifty years to live.
column3: He was still young-he was only four or five and twenty-he had nearly fifty years to live.

column2: What unforseen events might not open his prison door, and restore him to liberty?
column3: What unforseen events might not open his prison door, and restore him to liberty?

column2: Then he raised to his lips the repast that, like a voluntary Tantalus, he refused himself; but he thought of his oath, and he would not break it.
column3: Then he raised to his lips the repast that, like a voluntary Tantalus, he refused himself; but he thought of his oath, and he would not break it.

column2: He persisted until, at last, he had not sufficient strength to rise and cast his supper out of the loophole.
column3: He persisted until, at last, he had not sufficient strength to rise and cast his supper out of the loophole.

column2: The next morning he could not see or hear; the jailer feared he was dangerously ill.
column3: The next morning he could not see or hear; the jailer feared he was dangerously ill.

column2: Edmond hoped he was dying.
column3: Edmond hoped he was dying.

column2: Thus the day passed away.
column3: Thus the day passed away.

column2: Edmond felt a sort of stupor creeping over him which brought with it a feeling almost of content; the gnawing pain at his stomach had ceased; his thirst had abated; when he closed his eyes he saw myriads of lights dancing before them like the will-o'-the-wisps that play about the marshes.
column3: Edmond felt a sort of stupor creeping over him which brought with it a feeling almost of content; the gnawing pain at his stomach had ceased; his thirst had abated; when he closed his eyes he saw myriads of lights dancing before them like the will o'-the wisps that play about the marshes.

column2: It was the twilight of that mysterious country called Death!
column3: It was the twilight of that mysterious country called Death!

column2: Suddenly, about nine o'clock in the evening, Edmond heard a hollow sound in the wall against which he was lying.
column3: Suddenly, about nine o'clock in the evening, Edmond heard a hollow sound in the wall against which he was lying.

column2: So many loathsome animals inhabited the prison, that their noise did not, in general, awake him; but whether abstinence had quickened his faculties, or whether the noise was really louder than usual, Edmond raised his head and listened.
column3: So many loathsome animals inhabited the prison, that their noise did not, in general, awake him; but whether abstinence had quickened his faculties, or whether the noise was really louder than usual, Edmond raised his head and listened.

column2: It was a continual scratching, as if made by a huge claw, a powerful tooth, or some iron instrument attacking the stones.
column3: It was a continual scratching, as if made by a huge claw, a powerful tooth, or some iron instrument attacking the stones.

column2: Although weakened, the young man's brain instantly responded to the idea that haunts all prisoners--liberty!
column3: Although weakened, the young man's brain instantly responded to the idea that haunts all prisoners-liberty!

column2: It seemed to him that heaven had at length taken pity on him, and had sent this noise to warn him on the very brink of the abyss.
column3: It seemed to him that heaven had at length taken pity on him, and had sent this noise to warn him on the very brink of the abyss.

column2: Perhaps one of those beloved ones he had so often thought of was thinking of him, and striving to diminish the distance that separated them.
column3: Perhaps one of those beloved ones he had so often thought of was thinking of him, and striving to diminish the distance that separated them.

column2: No, no, doubtless he was deceived, and it was but one of those dreams that forerun death!
column3: No, no, doubtless he was deceived, and it was but one of those dreams that forerun death!

column2: Edmond still heard the sound.
column3: Edmond still heard the sound.

column2: It lasted nearly three hours; he then heard a noise of something falling, and all was silent.
column3: It lasted nearly three hours; he then heard a noise of something falling, and all was silent.

column2: Some hours afterwards it began again, nearer and more distinct.
column3: Some hours afterwards it began again, nearer and more distinct.

column2: Edmond was intensely interested.
column3: Edmond was intensely interested.

column2: Suddenly the jailer entered.
column3: Suddenly the jailer entered.

column2: For a week since he had resolved to die, and during the four days that he had been carrying out his purpose, Edmond had not spoken to the attendant, had not answered him when he inquired what was the matter with him, and turned his face to the wall when he looked too curiously at him; but now the jailer might hear the noise and put an end to it, and so destroy a ray of something like hope that soothed his last moments.
column3: For a week since he had resolved to die, and during the four days that he had been carrying out his purpose, Edmond had not spoken to the attendant, had not answered him when he inquired what was the matter with him, and turned his face to the wall when he looked too curiously at him; but now the jailer might hear the noise and put an end to it, and so destroy a ray of something like hope that soothed his last moments.

column2: The jailer brought him his breakfast.
column3: The jailer brought him his breakfast.

column2: Dantes raised himself up and began to talk about everything; about the bad quality of the food, about the coldness of his dungeon, grumbling and complaining, in order to have an excuse for speaking louder, and wearying the patience of his jailer, who out of kindness of heart had brought broth and white bread for his prisoner.
column3: Dantes raised himself up and began to talk about everything; about the bad quality of the food, about the coldness of his dungeon, grumbling and complaining, in order to have an excuse for speaking louder, and wearying the patience of his jailer, who out of kindness of heart had brought broth and white bread for his prisoner.

column2: Fortunately, he fancied that Dantes was delirious; and placing the food on the rickety table, he withdrew.
column3: Fortunately, he fancied that Dantes was delirious; and placing the food on the rickety table, he withdrew.

column2: Edmond listened, and the sound became more and more distinct.
column3: Edmond listened, and the sound became more and more distinct.

column2: There can be no doubt about it, thought he; "it is some prisoner who is striving to obtain his freedom.
column3: There can be no doubt about it, thought he; "it is some prisoner who is striving to obtain his freedom.

column2: Oh, if I were only there to help him!" Suddenly another idea took possession of his mind, so used to misfortune, that it was scarcely capable of hope--the idea that the noise was made by workmen the governor had ordered to repair the neighboring dungeon.
column3: Oh, if I were only there to help him!" Suddenly another idea took possession of his mind, so used to misfortune, that it was scarcely capable of hope-the idea that the noise was made by workmen the governor had ordered to repair the neighboring dungeon.

column2: It was easy to ascertain this; but how could he risk the question?
column3: It was easy to ascertain this; but how could he risk the question?

column2: It was easy to call his jailer's attention to the noise, and watch his countenance as he listened; but might he not by this means destroy hopes far more important than the short-lived satisfaction of his own curiosity?
column3: It was easy to call his jailer's attention to the noise, and watch his countenance as he listened; but might he not by this means destroy hopes far more important than the short-lived satisfaction of his own curiosity?

column2: Unfortunately, Edmond's brain was still so feeble that he could not bend his thoughts to anything in particular.
column3: Unfortunately, Edmond's brain was still so feeble that he could not bend his thoughts to anything in particular.

column2: He saw but one means of restoring lucidity and clearness to his judgment.
column3: He saw but one means of restoring lucidity and clearness to his judgment.

column2: He turned his eyes towards the soup which the jailer had brought, rose, staggered towards it, raised the vessel to his lips, and drank off the contents with a feeling of indescribable pleasure.
column3: He turned his eyes towards the soup which the jailer had brought, rose, staggered towards it, raised the vessel to his lips, and drank off the contents with a feeling of indescribable pleasure.

column2: He had often heard that shipwrecked persons had died through having eagerly devoured too much food.
column3: He had often heard that shipwrecked persons had died through having eagerly devoured too much food.

column2: Edmond replaced on the table the bread he was about to devour, and returned to his couch--he did not wish to die.
column3: Edmond replaced on the table the bread he was about to devour, and returned to his couch-he did not wish to die.

column2: He soon felt that his ideas became again collected--he could think, and strengthen his thoughts by reasoning.
column3: He soon felt that his ideas became again collected-he could think, and strengthen his thoughts by reasoning.

column2: Then he said to himself, "I must put this to the test, but without compromising anybody.
column3: Then he said to himself, "I must put this to the test, but without compromising anybody.

column2: If it is a workman, I need but knock against the wall, and he will cease to work, in order to find out who is knocking, and why he does so; but as his occupation is sanctioned by the governor, he will soon resume it.
column3: If it is a workman, I need but knock against the wall, and he will cease to work, in order to find out who is knocking, and why he does so; but as his occupation is sanctioned by the governor, he will soon resume it.

column2: If, on the contrary, it is a prisoner, the noise I make will alarm him, he will cease, and not begin again until he thinks every one is asleep."
column3: If, on the contrary, it is a prisoner, the noise I make will alarm him, he will cease, and not begin again until he thinks every one is asleep."

column2: Edmond rose again, but this time his legs did not tremble, and his sight was clear; he went to a corner of his dungeon, detached a stone, and with it knocked against the wall where the sound came.
column3: Edmond rose again, but this time his legs did not tremble, and his sight was clear; he went to a corner of his dungeon, detached a stone, and with it knocked against the wall where the sound came.

column2: He struck thrice. At the first blow the sound ceased, as if by magic.
column3: He struck thrice. At the first blow the sound ceased, as if by magic.

column2: Edmond listened intently; an hour passed, two hours passed, and no sound was heard from the wall--all was silent there.
column3: Edmond listened intently; an hour passed, two hours passed, and no sound was heard from the wall-all was silent there.

column2: Full of hope, Edmond swallowed a few mouthfuls of bread and water, and, thanks to the vigor of his constitution, found himself well-nigh recovered.
column3: Full of hope, Edmond swallowed a few mouthfuls of bread and water, and, thanks to the vigor of his constitution, found himself well nigh recovered.

column2: The day passed away in utter silence--night came without recurrence of the noise.
column3: The day passed away in utter silence-night came without recurrence of the noise.

column2: It is a prisoner, said Edmond joyfully.
column3: It is a prisoner, said Edmond joyfully.

column2: The night passed in perfect silence.
column3: The night passed in perfect silence.

column2: Edmond did not close his eyes.
column3: Edmond did not close his eyes.

column2: In the morning the jailer brought him fresh provisions--he had already devoured those of the previous day; he ate these listening anxiously for the sound, walking round and round his cell, shaking the iron bars of the loophole, restoring vigor and agility to his limbs by exercise, and so preparing himself for his future destiny.
column3: In the morning the jailer brought him fresh provisions-he had already devoured those of the previous day; he ate these listening anxiously for the sound, walking round and round his cell, shaking the iron bars of the loophole, restoring vigor and agility to his limbs by exercise, and so preparing himself for his future destiny.

column2: At intervals he listened to learn if the noise had not begun again, and grew impatient at the prudence of the prisoner, who did not guess he had been disturbed by a captive as anxious for liberty as himself.
column3: At intervals he listened to learn if the noise had not begun again, and grew impatient at the prudence of the prisoner, who did not guess he had been disturbed by a captive as anxious for liberty as himself.

column2: Three days passed--seventy-two long tedious hours which he counted off by minutes!
column3: Three days passed-seventy two long tedious hours which he counted off by minutes!

column2: At length one evening, as the jailer was visiting him for the last time that night, Dantes, with his ear for the hundredth time at the wall, fancied he heard an almost imperceptible movement among the stones.
column3: At length one evening, as the jailer was visiting him for the last time that night, Dantes, with his ear for the hundredth time at the wall, fancied he heard an almost imperceptible movement among the stones.

column2: He moved away, walked up and down his cell to collect his thoughts, and then went back and listened.

column3: All his furniture consisted of a bed, a chair, a table, a pail, and a jug. The bed had iron clamps, but they were screwed to the wood, and it would have required a screw driver to take them off.

column3: Oh, yes, yes; this instant, I entreat you.

column2: In a moment that part of the floor on which Dantes was resting his two hands, as he knelt with his head in the opening, suddenly gave way; he drew back smartly, while a mass of stones and earth disappeared in a hole that opened beneath the aperture he himself had formed.
column3: In a moment that part of the floor on which Dantes was resting his two hands, as he knelt with his head in the opening, suddenly gave way; he drew back smartly, while a mass of stones and earth disappeared in a hole that opened beneath the aperture he himself had formed.

column2: Then from the bottom of this passage, the depth of which it was impossible to measure, he saw appear, first the head, then the shoulders, and lastly the body of a man, who sprang lightly into his cell.
column3: Then from the bottom of this passage, the depth of which it was impossible to measure, he saw appear, first the head, then the shoulders, and lastly the body of a man, who sprang lightly into his cell.
